newsitem.title: ITALY: Secretive Italian bank opens doors to press.
newsitem.headline: Secretive Italian bank opens doors to press.

text.p: Italy's powerful and secretive merchant bank Mediobanca held the first news conference in its history on Friday but journalists got only a few paces beyond the front door.
Reporters were ushered into a cramped assembly room next to the bank's entrance with tiered desks, resembling a lecture hall, for a presentation on Austria's privatisation programme.
The door to the room was firmly shut as soon as the presentation got under way and a heavily built official of the bank stood conspicuously next to the exit.
Mediobanca's chairman Francesco Cingano chaired the meeting but Enrico Cuccia, the media-shy old man who has held sway over the bank's fortunes for half a century, was nowhere to be seen.

Cuccia, now approaching 90, carved out a pivotal role in Italian capitalism by spinning a web of alliances between business families in return for key shareholdings in blue chip companies such as car maker Fiat and tyre group Pirelli.
Widely seen as Italy's most elitist business institution, Mediobanca has traditionally disdained the media, which are allowed to attend only the bank's annual shareholders' meeting.
Now honorary chairman, Cuccia has never been known to grant an on-the-record interview to a journalist.
The bank does not have a media relations office and only occasionally issues very brief press statements.

By inviting officials from Austria -- northeast Italy's colonial master until the mid-nineteenth century -- to give an account of their swift progress in selling state assets Mediobanca appeared to send a veiled message to Italy's leaders.

Italy's privatisation programme has lagged behind those of many other European countries as the government has struggled to overcome opposition to selling key assets, including state telecommunications group Stet.

Italian journalists have speculated that the decision to allow the press inside Mediobanca may signal a change of style after the bank, increasingly perceived as stuffy and out-of-touch, suffered a series of spectacular reverses.

Mediobanca brokered a merger between textiles and fashion group Marzotto and HPI, a holding company created by spinning off the industrial interests of a company called Gemina, only to see its efforts come to nought when the deal collapsed in May.

The bank also suffered a huge embarrassment in 1995 when the "SuperGemina" deal to bundle the interests of financial holding company Gemina with the former Ferruzzi agri-chemicals empire was abandoned after huge losses at a Gemina unit came to light.
Italian newspaper commentators mused after the demise of the Marzotto deal that Mediobanca's power as a corporate dealmaker was on the wane.
